Lindleu 39urrat's adventure 7vith an EL-
ehhant-When l was in England. in the
year 1771, went to see the elephants which
were kept at the Queens stables, Bucking-
ham house.--Whilst | was gratifying myself
with observing the huge creatures, and their
various actions and peculiarities, took oc-
casion to withdraw from one OF them part
Of the hay which he was collecting on the
floor with his proboscis. did this with my
cane and watched the animal very narrow
ly. TO prevent stroke from him, which l
had reason to expect. The keeper said that
had greatly displeased the elephant. and
that he would never forget the injury.
thought but little of this sadmonitlon at the
time. But about six weeks afterwards,
when accompanied some other persons on
visit to the elephants, found that, though
probably several hundred people had been
there since my proceeding visit; the animal
soon recognized me. / did not attempt to
molest or tease him at all; and had no con-
ception of any concealed resentment-On a
sudden, however, when was supposed to
be within the reach Of his proboscis, he
threw II towards me- with such violence,


that had it struck me, | should probably


have been killed, or received some material
injury. Happily for me, perceived his in-


tention, and being very active, sprung out
of his reach. To every other person pres


ent, he was gentle and good tempered, and


his enmity to me arose, as the keeper de-
clared, solely from the circumstance of the
little affront which had formerly put upon


him.

had ceased to weep! Day after day, the
darkness that covered his brain grew less
and less deep--to her, that bewiderment
gave the blesscdness of hope-for her son
knew that he had an immortal soul, and one
evening joined family and feebly, and erring-
ly in prayer. A few weeks afterwards, he
remembered only events, and scenes long
past and distant; and believed that his father
and all his brothers and sisters were yet a.
live. He called upon them by their names,
to come and kiss him-on them, who had all
long been buried in the dust. But his soul
struggled itself into reason and remem-
brance, and he at last said, 'Mother! did
some accident befal me yesterday at my
work down the glen! feel weak and about
to die !'' The shadows of death were indeed
around him; but he lived to be told much OF
what had happened, and rendered up per-
fectly uncloudy spirit into the mercy OF his
Saviour. His mother felt that all her prayers
had been granted in that one boon, and when
the coffin was borne away from the eiling,
she remained in, with a friend, assured,
that in this world, there could for her be no
more grief. And in the same shciing, now
that years have gone by she still fingers, WIS.,
tied as often as she wishes, by her poor
neighbours, (for, to the poor. sorrow is sa-
cred thng,) who, by turns, send one of their
daughters to stay with her, and cheer lite
that cannot be long; but that end when it
may, will be laid down without one impious
misgiving, and in the humility of the Chris
tian's faith.

They are certainly very dangerous sect.
There is more peril to be encountered be-
meath one of their coal box drab Donnets, than
in all the eyes that ever shone through arti.
fetal flowers. That coquettish simplicity OF
dress, its perfect neatness so embamatic OF
purity, that latent smile, just sufficient to
dimple the cheek, without uttering sound,
and above all, the snow white stocking mt
ted exactly TO the foot that cannot bs s.n
cealed, have witchery about them which
we are snre never entered into the contem-
pation of the good and honest Penn.

How firmly is pride, the first OF sins'
seated in the bosom of man and how UNI
versal his sway! Of all the usurpers OF uh-
lawful authority in the human heart nc
seems most jealous Of power, and most teh"-
cious Of life. Which among them can ooas'
Of more extensive dominions'


In the bosoms of the great, the rich' the
mighty, the noble ones OF the EARTH his SOY,
reipntv is acknowledged, and his commands
reyered.


But who would suppose that he has aught
to do with the INDECENT cottager, the hi"era'
ble beeear, and the cowardly thiett YET
with them, however naughty ne IS ne Is
mean enough to dwell. From the KING on
the throne, through all the ranks and orders
in human society, down to the meanest OF
the race of man, his voice is heard, ana ms
power is felt.


have seen him in variety ct forms. and
in a multitude of places. The elder porn
of the grand deceiver, he Is we'll instructed
in the arts of deception.


have heard his voice, as bold as ihue-
pendence itself, when the shadow OF danger
would have prompted to flight. have
heard his voice, as imperious as that OF aes-
notisn. when the chains of servility were
clanking behind, have heard him boast
in strains which would have been tulsome IN
the mouth Of wealth itself, when dlstressial
poverty was his companion. How often nave
/ heard the language Of humility drop from
his lip, and the melting strains otpty, wher
his heart was as hard as the flint.
have seen him in the hnery of the fop-
in the plain garment OF the pharisee-nt thu
feast of the charitable--in the penurlou
meal of the avaricious. Alas | have seei
pride-in the animation of the minister a
the altar-in the fervour of devotion in tn
sackcloth of repentance. Where shall
s turn my eyes and not behold this hatefu
monster!


e What power is sufficient to invade hi
throne, and overthrow his dominion in tn
heart Of man. The assaults Of reason are a
in vain. Such weapons as are employed
reason, are too feeble to overthrow hi
throne, and wrest from him that kngdoI
where truth and humility ought to reign
But RELIGION can Wage war against PRIDE


He cannot withstand the artillery of Fleavel


When the thunders OF the law of God ope
upon him, his naughty looks fall, his might


arm becomes nervcless, and his throne, ,shoo


to the foundation, tumbles into ruins.


The grace of the gospel, with Almight
d power, tears up the last stone OF the tound


tions thereof. The sword of truth pierce
10 his swollen heart--and his dying groan


deep and long continued, tell the listenlr
'e seraphs, that another soul is made meet Il
, Heaven.


o gracious God (may every reader sa
rs how much of this bitter evil remains in n


bosom! how often, unperceived, does it mi
a gle with my best performances, renderi


my sacrifice imperfect, and my devotion il
be pure! Stretch out thine arm OF grace, a


remove pride from my heart:-Then sh
e! serve thee with glowing zeal and perfect


mility; then shall enjoy unutterable ha


piness, in thy love and favor. 0 speed
;r grant me this mercy. through Jesus Chr
e! my Lord.

From Blaok,vood's Magazine.

Equitable depice.-An Italian on his death
bed left little to his widow except tine horse
and favorite cat, desiring that the horse
might be sold and the price employed in
masses for his SOUL The widow sent the
horse and the cat to market. with an injunc-
tion to sell the horse for crown, but not ex-
cept the purchaser bought tie cat at four
hundred crowns In this way she with ease
to her conscience got the money for her own
use,
ANECDOTES.

ton: an example that was speedily followed
by people of every rank; so tlat the young
bride had the additional pleasure Of pre-
senting her beloved with handsome dover,
which satisfied their moderate wishes, and
crowned their humble happirtss.

A lady observed in company, how glori-
ous and useful body the sun is" Why,
YES. madam" said an Irish gentleman pres
ent, "the sun is very fine body, to be sure:
but in my opinion, the moon is much more
useful; for the moon affords light in the night
time, when we really want it; whereas we
have the sun with US in the day time when
we have no occasion for it,

well cut ham and the left leg of goose
"Pray, sir, what is the peculiar luxury of
left leg," "Sir, to conceive its luxury, you
must find that it is the only leg left.''

"King George III. once gave directions
for closing a gate and road in his own park
Of Richmond, which had been free to foot
messengers Tor many years. A citizen Of
Richmond, who found the road convenient
to the inhabitants of that village, took up
the cause for his neighbours. He contended,
that although the thorough fare might have
been originally an encroachment, it had be-
come public property by the lapse of time
and by prescriptive right. and that he should
compel the King to open it.-He brought
his suit, without hesltating, into court o.
Justice, and gained his cause. lAnd that
citizen was poor shoe maker.l

casion to withdraw from one OF them part
Of the hay which he was collecting on the
floor with his proboscis. did this with my
cane and watched the animal very narrow
ly. TO prevent stroke from him, which l
had reason to expect. The keeper said that
had greatly displeased the elephant. and
that he would never forget the injury.
thought but little of this sadmonitlon at the
time. But about six weeks afterwards,
when accompanied some other persons on
visit to the elephants, found that, though
probably several hundred people had been
there since my proceeding visit; the animal
soon recognized me. / did not attempt to
molest or tease him at all; and had no con-
ception of any concealed resentment-On a
sudden, however, when was supposed to
be within the reach Of his proboscis, he
threw II towards me- with such violence,


that had it struck me, | should probably


have been killed, or received some material
injury. Happily for me, perceived his in-


tention, and being very active, sprung out
of his reach. To every other person pres


ent, he was gentle and good tempered, and


his enmity to me arose, as the keeper de-
clared, solely from the circumstance of the
little affront which had formerly put upon


him.

had ceased to weep! Day after day, the
darkness that covered his brain grew less
and less deep--to her, that bewiderment
gave the blesscdness of hope-for her son
knew that he had an immortal soul, and one
evening joined family and feebly, and erring-
ly in prayer. A few weeks afterwards, he
remembered only events, and scenes long
past and distant; and believed that his father
and all his brothers and sisters were yet a.
live. He called upon them by their names,
to come and kiss him-on them, who had all
long been buried in the dust. But his soul
struggled itself into reason and remem-
brance, and he at last said, 'Mother! did
some accident befal me yesterday at my
work down the glen! feel weak and about
to die !'' The shadows of death were indeed
around him; but he lived to be told much OF
what had happened, and rendered up per-
fectly uncloudy spirit into the mercy OF his
Saviour. His mother felt that all her prayers
had been granted in that one boon, and when
the coffin was borne away from the eiling,
she remained in, with a friend, assured,
that in this world, there could for her be no
more grief. And in the same shciing, now
that years have gone by she still fingers, WIS.,
tied as often as she wishes, by her poor
neighbours, (for, to the poor. sorrow is sa-
cred thng,) who, by turns, send one of their
daughters to stay with her, and cheer lite
that cannot be long; but that end when it
may, will be laid down without one impious
misgiving, and in the humility of the Chris
tian's faith.

full articles.headline:
THE FAIR QUAKEIS.
From the London RepiaD.
full articles.article:
They are certainly very dangerous sect.
There is more peril to be encountered be-
meath one of their coal box drab Donnets, than
in all the eyes that ever shone through arti.
fetal flowers. That coquettish simplicity OF
dress, its perfect neatness so embamatic OF
purity, that latent smile, just sufficient to
dimple the cheek, without uttering sound,
and above all, the snow white stocking mt
ted exactly TO the foot that cannot bs s.n
cealed, have witchery about them which
we are snre never entered into the contem-
pation of the good and honest Penn.

full articles.headline: TEEy rEONITOR.
full articles.article:
How firmly is pride, the first OF sins'
seated in the bosom of man and how UNI
versal his sway! Of all the usurpers OF uh-
lawful authority in the human heart nc
seems most jealous Of power, and most teh"-
cious Of life. Which among them can ooas'
Of more extensive dominions'


In the bosoms of the great, the rich' the
mighty, the noble ones OF the EARTH his SOY,
reipntv is acknowledged, and his commands
reyered.


But who would suppose that he has aught
to do with the INDECENT cottager, the hi"era'
ble beeear, and the cowardly thiett YET
with them, however naughty ne IS ne Is
mean enough to dwell. From the KING on
the throne, through all the ranks and orders
in human society, down to the meanest OF
the race of man, his voice is heard, ana ms
power is felt.


have seen him in variety ct forms. and
in a multitude of places. The elder porn
of the grand deceiver, he Is we'll instructed
in the arts of deception.


have heard his voice, as bold as ihue-
pendence itself, when the shadow OF danger
would have prompted to flight. have
heard his voice, as imperious as that OF aes-
notisn. when the chains of servility were
clanking behind, have heard him boast
in strains which would have been tulsome IN
the mouth Of wealth itself, when dlstressial
poverty was his companion. How often nave
/ heard the language Of humility drop from
his lip, and the melting strains otpty, wher
his heart was as hard as the flint.
have seen him in the hnery of the fop-
in the plain garment OF the pharisee-nt thu
feast of the charitable--in the penurlou
meal of the avaricious. Alas | have seei
pride-in the animation of the minister a
the altar-in the fervour of devotion in tn
sackcloth of repentance. Where shall
s turn my eyes and not behold this hatefu
monster!


e What power is sufficient to invade hi
throne, and overthrow his dominion in tn
heart Of man. The assaults Of reason are a
in vain. Such weapons as are employed
reason, are too feeble to overthrow hi
throne, and wrest from him that kngdoI
where truth and humility ought to reign
But RELIGION can Wage war against PRIDE


He cannot withstand the artillery of Fleavel


When the thunders OF the law of God ope
upon him, his naughty looks fall, his might


arm becomes nervcless, and his throne, ,shoo


to the foundation, tumbles into ruins.


The grace of the gospel, with Almight
d power, tears up the last stone OF the tound


tions thereof. The sword of truth pierce
10 his swollen heart--and his dying groan


deep and long continued, tell the listenlr
'e seraphs, that another soul is made meet Il
, Heaven.


o gracious God (may every reader sa
rs how much of this bitter evil remains in n


bosom! how often, unperceived, does it mi
a gle with my best performances, renderi


my sacrifice imperfect, and my devotion il
be pure! Stretch out thine arm OF grace, a


remove pride from my heart:-Then sh
e! serve thee with glowing zeal and perfect


mility; then shall enjoy unutterable ha


piness, in thy love and favor. 0 speed
;r grant me this mercy. through Jesus Chr
e! my Lord.

full articles.headline: ANECDOTES.
full articles.article:
Equitable depice.-An Italian on his death
bed left little to his widow except tine horse
and favorite cat, desiring that the horse
might be sold and the price employed in
masses for his SOUL The widow sent the
horse and the cat to market. with an injunc-
tion to sell the horse for crown, but not ex-
cept the purchaser bought tie cat at four
hundred crowns In this way she with ease
to her conscience got the money for her own
use,

ton: an example that was speedily followed
by people of every rank; so tlat the young
bride had the additional pleasure Of pre-
senting her beloved with handsome dover,
which satisfied their moderate wishes, and
crowned their humble happirtss.

full articles.headline:
From Black,cood'S Edia,Jatrg MagaSiae.
THE WIDOW AND HER SON.
full articles.article:
From Blac6,cood's Ed;aJvg Magazine.


THE WIDOW AND HER SON.


Not more beautiful vale ever inspired


pastoral poet in Arcadia, nor did Scillan


shepherds of old, ever pipe to each othertor
prize Of oatcn reed, in a lovelicr nook than


where yon cottage stands, shaded but scarce
" sheltered, bv few birch trees. 1t is in
truth not cottage, but shelllng OF turf,
mart of The knool adheiing to the side OF the


mountain Not another dWeilng-evcn
small as itself within mic many direction.
Those goats that seem to walk where there


is no footing along the side Of the cllff CO. OF


themselves, to be milkei at evening, 10
house beyond the hill, without any barking


dog to send them home. There are many


foot paths, but all of sheep, except one,


leading through the coppice wood to the


distant kirk. The angler seldom disturbs
those shadows. and the heron has them to
himself, watching often, with motlonless
neck all dav long. Yet the sheiling is inhab-
tied, and has been so by the same persons,
| for good many years. You might look at
| it for hours, and yet see no one SO much as
| moving to the door. But alittle smoke hoy


ers over it-faint as mist, and nothing else


tells that within is life.


II is inhabited by widow, who once was


the happiest of wives. and lived far down the


p,en. where it is richly cultivated, in house


astir with many children. 1t SO happended


that in the course of nature, without any


extraordnary bereavement,, she outlived all


the household, except one, on whom fell the


sadest afaiction that can beiall human be-


inp-the utter lossofreason. For many years
after the death of her husband and all her


other children, this son was her support; and


there was no occasion to pity them IN their


Doverty. where all were Door. Her natu-


raI cheerfulness never f0rsook her, and al
though fallen back in the world, and Obliged
in her age. to live without many comforts


she once had known, yet all the past grad


nallv was softened into peace, and the widow


and her son were IN that sh ling as happy as
: anv family in the parish. lie worked all


kinds of work without, and she sat spinning


from morning till night within-a constant


occunation soothing to one before whose


mind past times might otherwise have come
too often, and that creates contentment by
he nndisturbed sameness and visible pro-
{ yression. Ifuot always at meals, the widow
: COW her sou for an hour or two every night,
and through out the whole Sabbath day
: ,cbev silent too, under the same roof; and


che l;k ed the stormy weather when the rams
, were m. for then he found some ingenious
! emnlovment within the sheiling, or cheer
G ed her with some book lent by friend, OF
e with the lively or plaintive music OF his ma
p tive hills. Sometimes, III her gratitude, sht
$ said she was happier now than when she hat
f MANY other causes to be so, and When occa
i sionally an acquaintance dropped IN upon ne ne.
: solitude, her face welcomed every one WITT
) a smile that spoke Of more than resignation
" nor was she averse to p n AXE OF the social
| ity of other huts, and sat sedate among youth
!, g., merriment. when summer or winter tes
is tival came round, and poverty reJoicea


the riches of contentment and innocence.
,s p,t her trials. great as they had beer
"A were not vet over, for this, her only sor
70 was laid nrostrate by fever; and when
, left his body. he survived hopelessly strick
> on in mind. His ewes so clear and INTEL
IN gent were now fixed in idoc'ty, or rolled
a bout unohservant Of all objects, living or dea'
4; To him all e,ther seemed the samoan
II if suffered. he would have lain down, like
.if creature void of understanding, IN ram
m snow not being able to find his way back t
4 manv paces from the hut. All thought ar
lis feeling had left him-so had speech--ai ID
IS moaning, as if in pain or wo, when nor
ps hut a mother could hear without shudderii
of but she heard it during the NIGHT as we
,ir as day, and only sometimes llttei up n
all ewes in PRAYER to God. An offer was maj
,w to send him to place where the aliilct
it. are taken care Of, but she bcseeched cha1
ir. ty for the first ,time-such aims as won
ng enable her, along will, the earnings OF n
nd wheel, to keep her son in the shelllng; a
of the means were given her from many qua
NO ter to do so descentlv, and with all the COZ
fe. forts that other eyes observed, but OF whl
hit the poor object himself was insenshle a
unconscious. Theneeforth, it may aims
yn be said, she never more saw the sun. \
ion heard the torrents roar She went mol 10
ra- kirk, but kept the Sabbath where the pa1
ate lvtic Law, and there sung the lone,y pSai
INK and said the lonely prayer, unhearo ~ ~
ost en-, as many despairing spirits @oulu na
for thoupht-but it is not so--tor IN TWO ysa
ace there came a meaning to his eyes am,
or, found a few words of imperfect speech, :,
,lic mong which was that of Mother. -
or how her heart burned within her TO kn =,
ne that her face was recognized 10 feel u y
,rt- her kiss was returned, and to see tNe n \
ma tear that trickled from her cres that Sc Il

full articles.article:
nights, when fierce north wind added to
the usual cold. His watch was the most ex-
posed situation of the place, and he had


scarcely recovered from severe indsposi-
ton; but he was soldier, and he declared


his readiness TO take his round. 1t chanced !
that he had pledged his affections to ayoung |
woman of the same city, who no sooner
heard of his being on duty, than she began


to lament bitterly, declaring it to be impossi-
bic for him to survive the insutferable sever
itv of such a night after the illness under


which he still fingered. Tormentei with
anxiety. she was unable to close her eyes, or
even to retire to rest; and as the night adj
vancee, the cold becoming more Intense, her
depicted him struggling against the fearful
elements, and his own weakness, and at
length, nc longer able to support himself, O.
ycrpowered with slumber, and sinking to G.
ternal rest upon the ground. Maddcncd at
the idea and needless OF consequences, she
hastily clothed herself as warmly as posi-
,ib]c. a;l,l ran out Of the house, situated not
tar from the place of watch, and with the
utmost courage arrived alone at the spot
And there she indeed found her poor solaier
nearly as exhausted as she had imagined,
being with difficulty able to keep MS le,t'
owing to the intenseness OF the frost. ShV
earnestly conjured him to hasten, though oh-
" fora little while, torevlye himself at hef
house, when, having taken sonle refresh
tmcnts he might return; but aware ut the


consequences of this he resolutcly, though


kindly. refused to do so. But only tor = few


minutes she continued, while you melt the


horrId frost which almost congeals you a


live Not an instant returned the soldier,


1T were certain death even to stir from the


SPOT Surely not, cried the affectlonate


pirl. il win never be known; and if you stay
your death will be still more certain; you
| have at least chance, and it is your duty,


if possible, to preserve your lite. Besides,


should YOUR absence happen to be discover
ed, heaven will take pity upon us, and pro-


vide in some way for your preservation. =


Yes suid the soldier, but that is not the
Iuuestion; for suppose | could doit with I'M
ipunity. is it noble or honorable thus vilely to


abandon my post without any one on guaras


4 bat there will ne some one, it you consent
to 90; will remain here until you return.
am not in the least afraid. SO be quick, and
give me YOUR arms This request she en-
forced with so much eloqucnce and tender
ness, and SO many tears, that the poor SOL


der, against his better judgment, was tain


to Weld, more especially as he telt himself
becoming fainter and fainter, and unable


much longer to resist the cold. Intending


to return within few minutes, he lett the


kind hearted girl in his place, wrapping her


in his cloak. and giving her his arms and


cap, together with the watch word, and such
was her delight at the idea of having saved
, the life Of her beloved, that she was tor time
i, inseDsible to the intense severity of the wea-


ther. But Just as she was flatterng herself
with the hope of his return, an officer made
. 1, ,to nc che F,r
t confusion to give the sign, suspected that
the soldier had either fallen asleep or fed
:, What was his surprise, on rushing to the
spot to find young girl overpowered will
e alarm. and unable to give any account y
n herself. from extreme agitation and tears
n Reinr conducted to the guard house, and re


stored to some degree of confidence. the poo


u;rl confessed the whole truth; soliciting
: with the anguish of doubt and distraction,
q nardon for her betrothcd husband. lie wa
!. instantly summoned from her house, but wa


found in such state of weakness from tn
III sufferinrs he had undergone, as to leav
at littlc prospect Of his surviving them. 1t wa
le with much difficulty, with the assistance Q
medical advice, that he was restored suit


c;entlv to give an ineligible account OF him
VI self after which he was placed in close Gus


todv to await the period of his trial. 'Fa
is hammer had it been for me- he exclaimed
lie on being restored to consciousness, far haT
II pier to have died at my post. than to be tht
" reserved for cruel and ignominlous death
'y The dav of his trial coming on, such VIZ
lis the polite severity of martial law, as he ha
m we'll foreseen, that he was condemned to
= executed within few days after his SCI


tence. Great as was his affiiction on hea
- inc these tidngs, it was little in comparisd
m with the remorse and terror that distracte
en- the breast of his beloved girl. who, in add
~ ton to the grief of losing him, in 50 publ


and enominious manner, accused herse
Oh as the cause of the calamity. He, to who


she had been so long and tenderly attache
ty vas now to fall as it were by the hand OF i
,- petrothed bride! Such was the strangene


and sudenness of the event, that her teeln
'es heinp wrought up to the highest pitch
rs, recitation and terror, her very despf
ng seemed to give her strength; and casting
for fear of consequences aside. she made vt vv


to save him or perish in the attempt. b


terlv weeping, and with dishevelled ha
w she ran wildly through the city, beseechi
my pity and compassion from all her friends a
in acquaintance, and soliciting every person
49, nix and influence. to unite in petition
"h foe pardon for her lover, or that her u
m she being the sole author OF the fault, mig
md be accepted in place of his.


Iall The circumstances being made kno,
=, such was the tenderness and compass

The seaman follows her, 10 fall at last
In yictory's CORY arms. To Learning's sons
She promises the proud degree, the praise
ofacademic senates, and name
That fame, on her imperishable scroll,
Shall deeply grave. 0, there was one VINO


heard


Her fatal promptings-whom the Muses. mourn,
And Genius yet dcplorcs! In stulious cell
Immur'd, he trimm'd his solitary lamp;
And morn, UNMARKED, upon his pald cheek
oftAung her ray, ere yet the sunken eye
Reluctant clos'd, and sleep around his couch
strew'd her poppies. Day with night
Mingled, insensibly, and night with day:
IN loyeliest change the seasons came-and


passd--


Boring woke and in her beautiful blue sky
WANDERED the lark-the merry birds beneath
Pour'd their sweet oodand poetry; the streams
Sent up their eloquent voces-all was joy;
And in tue breeze was life. Then Summer


gemmd


The award with flowers, as thickly strew'd as


seen


In heaven the countless clustering stars. BY day
The grateful peasant pourd his song--by night
The nightingae-he heard not tic lay
Divine of earth or sky-the voice of streams
Sunshine and shadow-and the rich blue sky;
For gales of fragrance and of life, that cheer
the aching brow-relume the dropping eye
And fire the languid pulse. One stern pursuit,
One master-passion, master'd all-and Death
Smil'd inly, as Consumption, at his nod,
Poison'd the springs Of life, and Aush'd the


cheek
With roses that bloom only o'er the grave
Andin that eve that once so wildly beam'd,
Kindled unnatural fires!


Yet Hope sustain'd
His sinking soul; and to the high reward
of slecpless nights, and watchfu days, and scorr
Ofpleasure, and the stern contempt of ease,
Pointed exultingly. But Death, who loves
To blast Hopes fairest visions, and to dash
In unsuspected hour, the cup of bliss
From mans impatient lip, with horrid glance,
Mark'd the young victim. as with flutt'ring step
And beating heart, and check with treacheron


bloom


suh'us'd, he press'd where Science ope'd tn


gates

A lady observed in company, how glori-
ous and useful body the sun is" Why,
YES. madam" said an Irish gentleman pres
ent, "the sun is very fine body, to be sure:
but in my opinion, the moon is much more
useful; for the moon affords light in the night
time, when we really want it; whereas we
have the sun with US in the day time when
we have no occasion for it,

full articles.article:

remark able for its long and inclement frost,
exnerienced with equal rigor throughout
Italv, France and Germany, where the lars-

A traveller was lately boasting of the lux
ury of arriving at night, after hard days
journey, to partake OF the enjoyment OF a
well cut ham and the left leg of goose
"Pray, sir, what is the peculiar luxury of
left leg," "Sir, to conceive its luxury, you
must find that it is the only leg left.''

tracted from women's tongues and lions
hearts; for when he had drunk a bottle OF It,
he said, he could talk forever and hight the
d. himself.

Glad TO hear it, Then suddenly added
With feeling Of compassionate forgiveness.
and vet don't see why ! should be, poor

"King George III. once gave directions
for closing a gate and road in his own park
Of Richmond, which had been free to foot
messengers Tor many years. A citizen Of
Richmond, who found the road convenient
to the inhabitants of that village, took up
the cause for his neighbours. He contended,
that although the thorough fare might have
been originally an encroachment, it had be-
come public property by the lapse of time
and by prescriptive right. and that he should
compel the King to open it.-He brought
his suit, without hesltating, into court o.
Justice, and gained his cause. lAnd that
citizen was poor shoe maker.l


Self has tvs eyes which must bc pnt out-SeN-
strength and self.rigNteousness.
